Posts.Content: Absolutely right, your cancer is hormone receptive - as was mine and I had to have my mirena removed after my lumpectomy. Don't wait for someone to explain or try to remember later to ask, try and ask why when you're told things or they will weigh on your mind. That's why I took my husband to every appointment (and continue to do so) All is not lost, you can still have a coil fitted but it has to be a normal one, not one that is hormone impregnated like the mirena. How old are you? Have you discussed the possibility of early menopause?
Posts.Title: contraception?

Posts.Content: Hi there. I am a Tamoxifen 'user' as you so delicately put it! I have only been taking it a few months and haven't seen any obvious effects on our relationship so I wonder what exactly is going on with you as you don't give much detail. I was talking to my doctor yesterday and he was explaining that the side effects are similar to menopause (I am in my 40's) and it's difficult to tel the 2 apart. That would explain the mood swings and the hot flushes. All I can tell you from my side is that don't take it personally, we still love you and want you around, it's just hard when your mind is all over the place! My husband would probably tell you to retreat to your shed! I have read some advice on here suggesting evening primrose oil, starflower oil etc but maybe your wife should see her GP? Anyway, good luck x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and relationships

Posts.Content: If you're looking for a magic food that helps with side effects or speeds recovery, I'm sorry to tell you there aren't any. There is good advice in this post about eating what you fancy but it's really what suits you. Listen to your body. I ate just about whatever I wanted, craving 'strong' tasting foods but had some horrible mouth ulcers which meant I didn't really feel like eating. Everyone is different so I hope you find something which suits you. In addition to my normal diet I have an Actimel (yuk!) everyday and a multi vitamin just to give things a boost. Good luck with your treatment x
Posts.Title: What's best to eat while on Chemo??

Posts.Content: donnaree, be bald and proud! Practice indoors and then venture out, start by putting the washing out or saying hello to the postman, you will be pleasantly surprised how nice people are, you will only find a few nasties that stare. Just be careful when bending over or putting your head in a cupboard, as you have no 'guide hairs' (like whiskers) you can easily bump your bonce! I got Mr Smelly to do mine with the clippers and it was a relief, now its just chilly! Check out my anniversary pic, I like to think I look like a fat Natalie Portman! Good luck, its not as scary as you think xx
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hey cookie, Like many of the ladies on here I have been to annabandana and have swooped on all the charity shop scarves (budget is £3 each) and ebay is good for classic vintage and silk scarves which have been much admired. Now the good weather is here, I have been going 'alfresco' and even sported the shiny pate look at a top notch restaurant at a special occasion on Weds night. People are very accepting and I have got to the point now where I think if someone stares then thats their problem, not mine. Have just noticed that ny eyebrows have nearly vanished but reckon I can draw them in if I need to, aftrerall if the Duchess of Cambridge can wear the look ......! I was more upset than I thought I would be but I feel the same as one of the other ladies, it's just another thing to tick off the list, it won't last forever and it's a new experience. I particularly like standing under the shower and listening to rain drops keep falling on my head..........!
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Bennie, Welcome :0) Don't be so worried about the 'commando' look. Our postie was kind enough to stop for a chat when he first saw my pate and told me all about his daughter's treatment and how he looked after his grandson.  She's been in the clear for a few years now. It really cheered me up and now when he sees me, he just nods at my head and asks 'how's it all going then?' It really came in handy when the canvassers were out for the local elections, you've never seen a clip board disappear so fast when I answered the door!! I have only seen one bad reaction when I was in a pub having some lunch when a woman sat down with her friend, caught sight of my bald tufty head and got up and moved. Silly cow, might be her one day or one of her friends. Be bald! Be proud :0) Mind you, its a pain when your eyelashes and eyebrows come out!!

Posts.Content: Well, I started to read all these posts and felt increasing anger at the selfishness of some 'patients' - also spelt PATIENCE!! I can't believe all the moaners and groaners complaining about how the medics aren't listening blah blah blah....... Have you people ever stopped to think how stressful it must be working in onology??! How many times you're asked he most ridiculous questions and how annoying it must be when patients think they are the only person in the world that has cancer??!These people have lives and families to hold together as well as treating some of the most seriously ill patients in the hospital. Why don't you stop and consider how lucky you are to be able to tap into the fantastic resource that is the NHS? And it's free! Why don't you stop and consider how much this treatment would cost you in the states or how you would be treated in a 3rd world country? Yes, I know that doesn't excuse poor customer service but have a heart! I'm quite ashamed of some of the pathetic whinging on here! Get a grip and grow a back bone people and be grateful for what you've got. I've been blessed with calm, considerate health professionals who have had nothing but my comfort and treatment at the forefront of their minds and I'm eternally grateful. So should you be!
Posts.Title: Getting them to listen

Posts.Content: Did your oncologist not tell you about the side effects? You aren't experiencing anything uncommon, however, you must eat and drink to keep your energy up and to help your body recover from the chemo. I got ulcers and a mouth like an arab's flip flop, Difflam did the trick for me too. I went right off tea and went on to hot squash or Peppermint cordial (which also helped with indigestion) Don't suffer in silence, ask your nurses for help

Posts.Content: This might be an unpopular suggestion but why don't you put in things that don't cost any money? A voucher for a lift to the hospital? A promise to do 2 weeks of housework? An offer to do some washing/ironing? Some home cooked meals? Cuddle vouchers? Personally, the things that meant alot to me while I was being treated were a home cooked daal and a lift to the hospital from a friend that has enough on her plate.
Posts.Title: chemo 'rescue kit' - suggestions please.

Posts.Content: Chill Gillian!! Of course it can be renewed. I got mine in April and realised that as I was going to have to have 5 years of tamoxifen, it was going to run out before I finished so I rang them up and asked and you can renew it and use another 5 years.It actually says on the back of the letter this: "If, at the end of 5 years, you still meet the conditions on the application form, you can apply for a new certificate" The telephone number for the medical exemption is 0845 601 8076. Don't be so ashamed of asking for stuff. If, like me, you've been a tax payer for all your working life then you are entitled to some help. Take no notice of your husband, he sounds like Captain Caveman. If ever you're in doubt ring the authorities yourself as not all advice on here is correct or up to date. And take no notice of the tree huggers and exercise nazis on here, you do your own thing! Hope this helps xx

Posts.Content: I think that this post really highlights the differences in PCT across the country. I feel blessed that I have been given brilliant, straight forward information that has been easy to follow, helpful, reassuring and informative (or perhaps I was just paying attention?) I have already been told that I will get my RT 3 weeks after the end of my chemo. The reason why they don't tell you everything at the beginining is that you'd probably go into melt down and wouldn't remember at thing. I have an appointment with my oncologist after the chemo finishes where, if its anything like the rest of the treatment, they will give me all the info then so I can ask questions and understand before treatment starts. I will be going to a different hospital and just hope that it matches up to the excellent care I have had under Medway PCT. As for the tattoos, I have those already so a few more battle scars doesn't bother me in the slightest, I'm just happy to be alive :0)

Posts.Content: Janet, I really know how you feel.  I had 15 sessions and 3 boosters. My husband told me how the machine worked and it freaked me out. Posts.Title: Dry, tired eyes

Posts.Content: Melatonin is mother nature's way of getting you to sleep and control the rhythms of sleep. I bought some coming back from Singapore and it really helped to re-establish my sleep patterns. You also need to have a 'go to bed' routine, which tells your body that it's time to sleep and can start to wind down. Turn the tv off, have a nice warm drink and make sure your bedroom is well ventilated and dark. Try and go at the same time every night even if your eyes are drooping and Mr Sandman has already made a delivery and if possible don't kip in the daytime. Works for me :0) Personally I would avoid too many strong sedatives as doctors seems to be all too keen to write a script without finding out the real cause of your distress. Still, you can always sell your temazepam on a street corner when you're down at the supermarket in your jamas at 3am! Good luck!

Posts.Title: In need of some reassurance.

Posts.Content: NG, I found your post very difficult to read and have found many similar on this site to be very depressing. I admire the way in which you have recognised your own health issues and by confronting them are dealing with them well. I am touched by your concern for your mother, have you thought of telling her how much you care for her in general and as you say, what upsets her, upsets you. Some people are 'fixers' and feel that they need to mend or fix a situation when all we need is a friendly ear and compassion, just talking sometimes can make you feel better. Perhaps you have other family members or close friends that could help shoulder the burden and don't be afraid to ask, I have found that help can come from the most unexpected quarters! Even the smallest gesture can speak volumes. An offer to cook for me recently really raised my spirits. Having breast cancer is not a death sentence, it's a reason to live and although your mother's prognosis sounds grim, please try to look on the postitive side. You will find on this forum (within the gloom and doom) some very good advice and some occasional hilarious nuggets of humour. It's a very supportive community and you are never alone. Good luck x
